name: COVID-19 pandemic cases (various jurisdictions 2020-2023)
summary: Global pandemic prompted extensive litigation establishing that pandemic effects may constitute force majeure depending on specific clause wording and causal connection to performance difficulties.

concepts.principleName: The Legal Concept of Force Majeure
concepts.fieldOfLaw: Construction Law - Risk Allocation and Excuse

name: Various Claimants v WM Morrison Supermarkets [2020] UKSC 12
summary: Supreme Court clarified limits of vicarious liability, holding employer not liable for employee's personal vendetta despite using work facilities, emphasizing need for genuine connection to employment role.

concepts.principleName: The Doctrine of Vicarious Liability

name: MT HÃ¸jgaard A/S v E.ON Climate & Renewables UK Robin Rigg East Limited
summary: Supreme Court confirmed fitness for purpose obligations can arise even where design complies with applicable standards, emphasizing the absolute nature of the duty and insurance implications.

concepts.principleName: The Implied Duty of Fitness for Purpose

name: Coventry v Lawrence [2014] UKSC 13
summary: Supreme Court clarified that statutory authorization provides limited defense to nuisance claims, and planning permission doesn't automatically authorize nuisance-level interference.

concepts.principleName: The Law of Nuisance as Applied to Construction Sites (e.g., dust, noise)

name: Woodland v Essex County Council
summary: Supreme Court established comprehensive framework for non-delegable duties, holding that a school owed pupils a non-delegable duty to ensure swimming lessons were conducted with reasonable care, creating liability for independent swimming instructor's negligence.

concepts.principleName: The Concept of a Non-Delegable Duty of Care

name: Various Claimants v Institute of the Brothers of the Christian Schools [2012] UKSC 56
summary: Supreme Court extended non-delegable duty concept beyond traditional categories, focusing on relationships where defendant assumed responsibility for claimant's welfare and safety.

concepts.principleName: The Concept of a Non-Delegable Duty of Care

name: Stannard v Gore [2012] EWCA Civ 1248
summary: Court of Appeal applied rule to fire spreading from deliberate burning of tires, confirming continued relevance for construction activities involving fire or combustible materials.

concepts.principleName: The Rule in Rylands v Fletcher (Strict Liability)

name: John Doyle Construction Ltd v Laing Management (Scotland) Ltd [2004] BLR 295
summary: Scottish court clarified that global claims must still establish causal connection and cannot be used simply to avoid burden of detailed analysis where separation is possible.

concepts.principleName: The Principles Governing 'Global Claims'

name: Transco plc v Stockport MBC [2003] UKHL 61
summary: House of Lords clarified 'non-natural use' test, emphasizing extraordinary risk creation rather than mere artificiality, and rejected calls to abolish the rule entirely.

concepts.principleName: The Rule in Rylands v Fletcher (Strict Liability)

name: Amiri Flight Authority v BAE Systems plc [2003] EWCA Civ 1447
summary: Court of Appeal emphasized need for incorporated terms to be consistent with express contract terms and established hierarchy where express terms prevail over incorporated terms in case of conflict.

concepts.principleName: The Doctrine of Incorporation of Terms by Reference

name: Dubai Aluminium Co Ltd v Salaam [2002] UKHL 48
summary: House of Lords modernized test for vicarious liability by focusing on 'close connection' between employment and wrongful act, moving away from rigid 'course of employment' formulation.

concepts.principleName: The Doctrine of Vicarious Liability

name: Motherwell Bridge Construction Ltd v Micafil Vakuumtechnik
summary: Foundational authority establishing the legal framework for the concept of constructive acceleration of works in construction and commercial law contexts.

concepts.principleName: The Concept of Constructive Acceleration of Works

name: Farley v Skinner [2001] UKHL 49
summary: House of Lords extended Ruxley principles to surveyor negligence, confirming availability of damages for non-pecuniary loss where parties contemplated peace of mind as contractual objective.

concepts.principleName: The 'Cost of Cure' vs. 'Loss of Amenity' Principle (Ruxley v Forsyth)

name: Serck Controls Ltd v Drake & Scull Engineering Ltd
summary: English court addressed total cost methodology, emphasizing need to establish causal connection between compensable events and cost overruns while excluding contractor's own inefficiencies.

concepts.principleName: The Principles Governing 'Total Cost' Claims

name: Credit Lyonnais Bank Nederland NV v Burch
summary: Foundational authority establishing the legal framework for the doctrine of unconscionability in contractual bargains in construction and commercial law contexts.

concepts.principleName: The Doctrine of Unconscionability in Contractual Bargains

name: Ruxley Electronics and Construction Ltd v Forsyth
summary: House of Lords established that where cost of rectifying construction defects is wholly disproportionate to any benefit obtained, courts should award damages for loss of amenity rather than full reinstatement costs, even where no diminution in value can be proven.

concepts.principleName: The 'Cost of Cure' vs. 'Loss of Amenity' Principle (Ruxley v Forsyth)

name: Ruxley Electronics v Forsyth
summary: Foundational authority establishing the legal framework for the 'no loss' defence in claims for breach in construction and commercial law contexts.

concepts.principleName: The 'No Loss' Defence in Claims for Breach

name: Cambridge Water Co v Eastern Counties Leather [1994] 2 AC 264
summary: House of Lords modernized the rule by requiring reasonable foreseeability of damage type, limiting strict liability while maintaining core principle for industrial activities.

concepts.principleName: The Rule in Rylands v Fletcher (Strict Liability)

name: Coloroll Pension Trustees Ltd v Russell [1994] 4 All ER 33
summary: House of Lords clarified that conditions precedent to performance suspend existing obligations rather than preventing contract formation, affecting remedy availability.

concepts.principleName: The Legal Status of a Condition Precedent

name: Lord Napier and Ettrick v Hunter
summary: Foundational authority establishing the legal framework for the doctrine of subrogation in insurance matters in construction and commercial law contexts.

concepts.principleName: The Doctrine of Subrogation in Insurance Matters

name: Lin v Gatehouse Construction Co
summary: Established that any contract to perform work imposes on the contractor the duty to perform the work in a workmanlike manner, defined as the way work is customarily done by other contractors in the community.

concepts.principleName: The Obligation to Perform in a 'Good and Workmanlike Manner'

name: Mid Glamorgan County Council v J Devonald Williams & Partner (1992) 29 Con LR 129
summary: Established that global claims require proof of causation between events claimed for and loss suffered, rejecting purely arithmetical approaches.

concepts.principleName: The Principles Governing 'Global Claims'

name: Murphy v Brentwood District Council
summary: Foundational authority establishing the legal framework for the principles underpinning collateral warranties in construction and commercial law contexts.

concepts.principleName: The Principles Underpinning Collateral Warranties

name: Motor Oil Hellas (Corinth) Refineries SA v Shipping Corp of India [1990] 1 Lloyd's Rep 391
summary: House of Lords clarified requirements for waiver by estoppel: clear representation, reliance, and detriment, making it harder to establish than election.

concepts.principleName: The Doctrine of Waiver (Waiver by Election and Waiver by Estoppel)

name: Channel Island Ferries Ltd v Sealink UK Ltd [1988] 1 Lloyd's Rep 323
summary: Confirmed that force majeure clauses must be strictly construed according to their terms, with courts unable to extend defined events beyond contractual language.

concepts.principleName: The Legal Concept of Force Majeure
concepts.fieldOfLaw: Construction Law - Risk Allocation and Excuse

name: Circle Freight International Ltd v Medeast Gulf Exports Ltd [1988] 2 Lloyd's Rep 427
summary: Clarified that incorporation requires clear identification of document version and date, particularly important for evolving standards and conditions.

concepts.principleName: The Doctrine of Incorporation of Terms by Reference

name: McDermid v Nash Dredging [1987] AC 906
summary: House of Lords established employer's non-delegable duty to provide safe system of work for employees, creating liability for negligent systems even when operated by independent contractors.

concepts.principleName: The Concept of a Non-Delegable Duty of Care

name: Anchor Brewhouse Developments Ltd v Berkley House (Docklands Developments) Ltd
summary: Foundational authority establishing the legal framework for the law of trespass as applied to construction (e.g., crane oversailing) in construction and commercial law contexts.

concepts.principleName: The Law of Trespass as Applied to Construction (e.g., crane oversailing)

name: National Carriers Ltd v Panalpina (Northern) Ltd [1981] AC 675
summary: House of Lords confirmed frustration can apply to leases and established that temporary impossibility insufficient unless it effectively destroys the contract's commercial purpose.

concepts.principleName: The Doctrine of Frustration of Contract

name: Bremer Handelsgesellschaft mbH v Westzucker GmbH [1981] 2 Lloyd's Rep 130
summary: Established that knowledge of facts giving rise to right is essential for valid waiver by election - cannot elect between rights without knowing they exist.

concepts.principleName: The Doctrine of Waiver (Waiver by Election and Waiver by Estoppel)

name: IBA v EMI Electronics and BICC Construction Ltd
summary: Clarified that design and build contractors owe fitness for purpose obligations for design elements unless contract terms limit liability to reasonable skill and care standard.

concepts.principleName: The Implied Duty of Fitness for Purpose

name: British Anzani (Felixstowe) Ltd v International Marine Management (UK) Ltd
summary: Foundational authority establishing the legal framework for the equitable principle of set-off in construction and commercial law contexts.

concepts.principleName: The Equitable Principle of Set-Off

name: Greaves & Co (Contractors) Ltd v Baynham Meikle & Partners
summary: Established that where a contractor undertakes design responsibility and the intended purpose is made known, fitness for purpose obligation is implied even for professional services.

concepts.principleName: The Implied Duty of Fitness for Purpose

name: British Crane Hire Corp Ltd v Ipswich Plant Hire Ltd
summary: Court of Appeal established requirements for successful incorporation: clear reference to external terms, reasonable notice that terms would apply, and consistency between parties' dealings and incorporated terms.

concepts.principleName: The Doctrine of Incorporation of Terms by Reference

name: Kammins Ballrooms Co Ltd v Zenith Investments (Torquay) Ltd
summary: House of Lords distinguished waiver by election (irrevocable choice between inconsistent rights) from waiver by estoppel (preventing unconscionable departure from induced assumptions).

concepts.principleName: The Doctrine of Waiver (Waiver by Election and Waiver by Estoppel)

name: Joscelyne v Nissen
summary: Foundational authority establishing the legal framework for the doctrine of rectification for common mistake in construction and commercial law contexts.

concepts.principleName: The Doctrine of Rectification for Common Mistake

name: Young & Marten Ltd v McManus Childs Ltd
summary: Established that contractors supplying materials impliedly warrant their fitness for purpose unless expressly excluded, extending Sale of Goods Act principles to construction contracts.

concepts.principleName: The Implied Duty of Fitness for Purpose

name: Crosby (J) & Sons Ltd v Portland UDC
summary: First recognition that where multiple causes of delay are so complex and interrelated that separation is impractical, global claims may be acceptable if overall causal connection established.

concepts.principleName: The Principles Governing 'Global Claims'

name: Davis Contractors Ltd v Fareham Urban District Council [1956] AC 696
summary: Lord Radcliffe provided classic definition: frustration occurs when performance becomes incapable due to circumstances rendering it radically different from what was undertaken by the contract.

concepts.principleName: The Doctrine of Frustration of Contract

name: Trans Trust SPRL v Danubian Trading Co Ltd
summary: Court of Appeal established distinction between conditions precedent to formation of contract versus conditions precedent to performance of existing contractual obligations.

concepts.principleName: The Legal Status of a Condition Precedent

name: Cassidy v Ministry of Health [1951] 2 KB 343
summary: Early recognition that hospitals owed patients non-delegable duties to ensure competent medical treatment, regardless of whether doctors were employees or independent contractors.

concepts.principleName: The Concept of a Non-Delegable Duty of Care

name: Fibrosa Spolka Akcyjna v Fairbairn Lawson Combe Barbour Ltd
summary: Foundational authority establishing the legal framework for the doctrine of total failure of consideration in construction and commercial law contexts.

concepts.principleName: The Doctrine of Total Failure of Consideration

name: Andreae v Selfridge & Co Ltd
summary: Court of Appeal established that temporary building operations causing noise, dust, and vibration can constitute nuisance if unreasonable in nature, timing, or duration, but some interference must be tolerated as inevitable.

concepts.principleName: The Law of Nuisance as Applied to Construction Sites (e.g., dust, noise)

name: Lebeaupin v Crispin [1920] 2 KB 714
summary: Defined force majeure as 'all circumstances beyond the will of man, and which it is not in his power to control', establishing that war, floods, epidemics and strikes constitute force majeure events.

concepts.principleName: The Legal Concept of Force Majeure
concepts.fieldOfLaw: Construction Law - Risk Allocation and Excuse

name: Matsoukis v Priestman
summary: English court first extensively interpreted force majeure clause, holding it covered business dislocation from universal coal strike but not routine events like bad weather, establishing distinction between extraordinary and ordinary business risks.

concepts.principleName: The Legal Concept of Force Majeure
concepts.fieldOfLaw: Construction Law - Risk Allocation and Excuse

name: Harrison v Southwark and Vauxhall Water Co [1891] 2 Ch 409
summary: Established that nuisance liability can exist even for lawful activities conducted with reasonable care, focusing on unreasonable interference rather than fault.

concepts.principleName: The Law of Nuisance as Applied to Construction Sites (e.g., dust, noise)

name: The Moorcock
summary: Foundational authority establishing the legal framework for the 'officious bystander' test for implied terms in construction and commercial law contexts.

concepts.principleName: The 'Officious Bystander' Test for Implied Terms

name: Rylands v Fletcher
summary: House of Lords established that those bringing dangerous substances onto land for non-natural use are strictly liable for damage caused by escape, regardless of fault. Fletcher's mill flooded when Rylands' reservoir burst through abandoned mine shafts.

concepts.principleName: The Rule in Rylands v Fletcher (Strict Liability)

name: Taylor v Caldwell
summary: Established frustration doctrine when music hall burnt down before contracted concerts, holding parties discharged from performance where subject matter destroyed without fault. This created exception to absolute contractual obligations principle from Paradine v Jane.

concepts.principleName: The Doctrine of Frustration of Contract

name: Limpus v London General Omnibus Co (1862) 1 H & C 526
summary: Extended vicarious liability to acts expressly forbidden by employer, establishing that prohibition does not necessarily take conduct outside course of employment if closely connected to authorized duties.

concepts.principleName: The Doctrine of Vicarious Liability

name: Pym v Campbell (1856) 6 E&B 370
summary: Established that conditions precedent to contract formation prevent any contractual obligations arising until condition satisfied, distinguished from conditions precedent to performance.

concepts.principleName: The Legal Status of a Condition Precedent

name: Scott v Avery
summary: Foundational authority establishing the legal framework for the scott v avery clause (arbitration as a precondition to litigation) in construction and commercial law contexts.

concepts.principleName: The Scott v Avery Clause (Arbitration as a Precondition to Litigation)

name: Lumley v Gye
summary: Foundational authority establishing the legal framework for the economic torts (e.g., inducing breach of contract) in construction and commercial law contexts.

concepts.principleName: The Economic Torts (e.g., Inducing Breach of Contract)

name: Joel v Morison
summary: Established foundational principle that masters are liable for servants' acts performed in course of employment, even where master had no knowledge or approval of the specific act causing harm.

concepts.principleName: The Doctrine of Vicarious Liability

name: Dering v Earl of Winchelsea
summary: Foundational authority establishing the legal framework for the equitable maxim of 'clean hands' in construction and commercial law contexts.

concepts.principleName: The Equitable Maxim of 'Clean Hands'
